statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: North Carolina State had no trouble staying unbeaten Friday night.
article.headline: Wolfpack shoot 70 percent in the second half
article.linkText: NC State makes it four blowouts in a row
article.story: RALEIGH, N.C. (AP) -- North Carolina State sure isn't letting underdog opponents find any glimmer of hope against them. Cameron Bennerman scored 20 points to lead the Wolfpack (No. 16 ESPN/USA Today, No. 17 AP) past Campbell 99-44, marking their fourth straight lopsided victory. Julius Hodge added 16 points, seven rebounds and seven assists for the Wolfpack (4-0), who again jumped out to a big lead and never faced even a hint of danger in a home nonconference game. "We feel pretty good right now with our defense and offense," said Tony Bethel, who had six assists and three steals. "But it is going to get tougher as we play tougher teams." Diago Aguiar scored 16 points for the Fighting Camels (1-2), who have lost 24 of 25 games against Atlantic Coast Conference teams. The Fighting Camels' only win against an ACC foe came 11 years ago against the Wolfpack, a 72-69 overtime win in Reynolds Coliseum. But there was no chance of an upset Friday night, with the Wolfpack handing Campbell its worst loss since moving to Division I in 1977. Campbell's previous worst defeat in Division I was a 96-43 loss at Florida International in February 1998. The Wolfpack hit plenty of 3-pointers and harassed Campbell ballhandlers with aggressive defense. The Wolfpack hit 14 of 26 shots from behind the arc -- including an 8-for-11 effort after halftime -- and held their instate neighbors to 33 percent shooting. The Wolfpack came into the game with three wins by an average margin of 30 points, and again had no shortage of gaudy statistics. N.C. State shot 59 percent for the game, including 70 percent in the second half. The Wolfpack had 27 assists against just six turnovers. And N.C. State nearly cracked the 100-point mark for the second straight game, which has been accomplished just three times in nine seasons under coach Herb Sendek. But perhaps most impressive in this four-game run has been the Wolfpack's ability to jump on teams from the opening tip. N.C. State cruised through the BCA Invitational last week, opening leads of 11-0, 13-2 and 13-0 while shooting 57 percent. On Friday, the Wolfpack took a 20-4 lead and used another burst immediately after halftime to knock out the Fighting Camels. "We've had pretty good leadership," Sendek said. "You listen to their comments among themselves. Guys have done a really good job of getting ready to play. ... They play because they really like it and they take a lot of pride in it." Bennerman said the Wolfpack has a chip on its shoulder and a point to prove. The point? "We're a good team," he said. "We're trying to be very consistent to back up that point." Consider Campbell coach Robbie Laing convinced. "They didn't allow us in the offense early," Laing said. "They're a very sound team. The most impressive thing about them is they play as a unit on both ends of the court. ... Their defense is downright impressive. It's just swarming. It's overwhelming." N.C. State's lead grew to 20 points midway through the first half, with the Wolfpack going 5-for-6 from behind the arc in those opening 10 minutes. The last of that stretch was a wide-open 3 from Ilian Evtimov just in front of the Campbell bench, prompting Laing to slump in his chair and throw his arms back in frustration. N.C. State led 41-22 at halftime and sucked any remaining drama out of the game by scoring the first 13 points after the break -- ending with a stickback inside from Cedric Simmons -- for a 32-point lead. By that time, Campbell had just one assist and 15 turnovers. The Fighting Camels finished with 21 turnovers, leading to 27 points for the Wolfpack. "I think we helped them pour it on," Laing said. "We threw it right to them." Anthony Atkinson, who came in leading Campbell with 15 points per game, finished with just five and struggled against Bethel and the Wolfpack defense. One of his two baskets was a goaltended layup midway through the second half.
